reviews.review:
Most people keep recommending Half-Life over Half-Life: Source, but I honestly don't see why. This one looks better, the first things I noticed is the improved lights and shadows, better water effects and added reflections to surfaces and guns. The physics also seem improved over the base game. This one also seems to be easier, enemies take less damage and you find a lot more ammo. I barely died, besides the one hit death traps.

At the end it's up to each person wich version one prefers, but I would definitely go with this one.

Time to complete it: 7,6 hours

Good morning and welcome to the Black Mesa Transit System. This automated train is provided for the security and convenience of the Black Mesa Research Facility personnel. The time is 08:47 AM. Current topside temperature is 93 degrees, with an estimated high of one hundred and five. The Black Mesa compound is maintained at a pleasant 68 degrees at all times. This train is inbound from Level 3 Dormitories to Sector C Test Labs and Control Facilities. If your intended destination is a high-security area beyond Sector C, you will need to return to the Central Transit Hub in Area 9 and board a high security train. If you have not yet submitted your identity to the retinal clearance system, you must report to Black Mesa Personnel for processing before you will be permitted into the high security branch of the transit system. Due to the high toxicity of material routinely handled in the Black Mesa compound, no smoking, eating, or drinking are permitted within the Black Mesa Transit System. Please keep your limbs inside the train at all times. Do not attempt to open the doors until the train has come to a complete halt at the station platform. In the event of an emergency, passengers are to remain seated and await further instruction. If it is necessary to exit the train, disabled personnel should be evacuated first. Please stay away from electrified rails, and proceed to an emergency station until assistance arrives. A reminder that the Black Mesa Hazard Course decathlon will commence this evening at nineteen hundred hours in the Level 3 Facility. The semifinals for high-security personnel will be announced in a separate Secure Access transmission. Remember, more lives than your own may depend on your fitness. Do you have a friend or relative who would make a valuable addition to the Black Mesa team? Immediate openings are available in the areas of Materials Handling and Low-Clearance Security. Please contact Black Mesa Personnel for further information. If you have an associate with a background in the areas of theoretical physics, biotechnology or other high tech disciplines, please contact our Civilian Recruitment Division. The Black Mesa Research Facility is an equal opportunity employer. A reminder to all Black Mesa Personnel: Regular radiation and biohazard screenings are a requirement of continued employment in the Black Mesa Research Facility. Missing a scheduled urinalysis or radiation check-up is grounds for immediate termination. If you feel you have been exposed to radioactive or other hazardous materials in the course of your duties, contact your Radiation Safety Officer immediately. Work safe, work smart. Your future depends on it. Now arriving at Sector C Test Labs and Control Facilities. Please stand back from the automated door and wait for the security officer to verify your identity. Before exiting the train, be sure to check your area for personal belongings. Thank you and have a very safe and productive day.

[h1]Half-Life Source is a Crappy way to play the original Half-Life.[/h1]

This so-called port to the source engine is not really the best way to play Half-Life today, but it's a okay experience.

[b]The reason why I can't recommend Half-Life Source is because it's Buggy is all Hell.[/b] There are No Official or Unofficial Patches for this game, [i][u]so instead I would recommend the original Half-Life over this one.[/u] But if you really want to play this version for some reason[/i], then [b]I will leave a Guide here[/b] showing you some [b]"Cosmetic fixes"[/b] you need, a few [b]tweaks[/b], and some [b]third-party programs[/b] you need to [i]open[/i] or [i]extract[/i] certain files.

[u]If you want a full review of this game, go read my Half Life review.[/u] https://steamcommunity.com/id/038G8J027IG10MOSQ/recommended/70/

[h1]--------------------------------------------------------[/h1]
[list]
[*][b][u]GCFScape[/u][/b]
http://nemesis.thewavelength.net/?p=26
This program will let you open VPK files, a little something you need for this guide.

[*][b][u]WinRAR[/u][/b]
https://www.win-rar.com/download.html?&L=0
You do need WinRAR to extract these files.

[*][b][u]Weird and ugly shine effects on walls and Floors.[/u][/b]
Type in the developer console mat_specular 0 or +mat_specular 0 in your lunch options.

[*][b][u]Graphical Glitches in Chapter 10: Residue Processing.[/u][/b]
Disable Multi-core Rendering in the Advanced Options menu.

[*][b][u]Installing skins or custom stuff in Source Games...[/u][/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=502670746
This guide will show you how to install custom mods, skins, and sounds in any Source game. [i]If you already know how to do this you can skip this.[/i]

[*][b][u]"Source Engine Sound Replacements"...[/u][/b]
https://gamebanana.com/sounds/42766
This fixes or changes the sound effects to the original GoldSrc sounds. for some reason it uses the source engines default sound effects, which to me sounds out of place for the original Half-Life. This mod is Optionable.

[*][b][u]"HL:S Sound fixes"...[/u][/b]
https://gamebanana.com/sounds/19654
This fixes even more sound effects.

[*][b][u]"Hafl-life 1 Blood Style"...[/u][/b]
https://gamebanana.com/effects/5461
This is a Black Mesa mod, but it also works in HL:S as well.
What you need to do to get this effect to work is to...

-Open the [i]"HLBloodStyle.vpk"[/i] and then extract the files anywhere or to your custom folder.

-Open the particles folder and rename [i]"fx_blood.pcf"[/i] to [i]"blood_impact.pcf"[/i] and remove [i]"gib_fx.pcf"[/i].

After that you'll get Half-Life's classic blood effect as seen here...
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1936813944

[*][b][u]"Half-Life 1 Blood Decals"...[/u][/b]
https://gamebanana.com/effects/5580
This is a Counter-Strike source decals mod, but it is compatible with HL:S. 

[*][h1][u]For people that wants to use the Low-Poly models...[/u][/h1]
The original low-poly models work great with no problems. 
The only fix you need is the [b]Glock Hand fix...[/b]
https://gamebanana.com/skins/144593
Which does what it says.

[*][h1][u]For people that wants to use the High-Definition models...[/u][/h1]
There is a little checkbox in the options menu for HD models. Most of the weapon models do work but have missing reloading sounds. This mod fixes these problem.
https://github.com/ValveSoftware/Source-1-Games/issues/1345#issuecomment-213631124
The animations are a bit janky, but they do work for the most part.
[/list]
Fixing the "Gibs" sounds is kinda tricky. I'll tell you the file names and where you should put these WAV files. Fixing the sounds involves some modification which you have to do yourself.
[spoiler]AKA, "You need to make falling meat sounds"[/spoiler]
[code]
"File Location"
[i]custom\"folder you've name"\sound\physics\plastic[/i]

-plastic_box_impact_hard1.wav
-plastic_box_impact_hard2.wav
-plastic_box_impact_hard3.wav

-plastic_box_impact_soft1.wav
-plastic_box_impact_soft2.wav
-plastic_box_impact_soft3.wav
[/code]

And that's pretty much it, if you really wanna know how buggy this version is or if someone is willing to fix these bugs, go watch [u]"Defenestrum Discusses ~ Half Life: Source Glitches Volume 1 and 2"[/u].

Have you ever played Half-Life and wondered, "Man, if only this game had ragdoll physics and more high quality water textures," like some sort of uncreative office worker waiting for the day they finally get to work in a slightly nicer office on different mundane tasks? Well, boy, do I have the game for you! Half-Life: Source adds all of those things and [i]nothing else![/i] It's all a man could ever ask for if they have no standards whatsoever!

But for real, the only reason you could ever end up buying this game is if you wanted to play with Half-Life assets in Garry's Mod. Or if you accidentally bought it with the Valve Complete Pack.

Half Life when it came out for the first it was the best thing ever. It made fps games come alive for gamer's as well! Then spawned games like Counter strike which to this day is amazing and from the same engine, as well as team fortress! Good games  even now. 

So I have to say 10/10
amazing

Since I already did a extensive review for the Original game, I'm going to got down the lazy route and do a small Pro and Con list *wink* *wink*

Pros:
[list]
    [*] Completely new Ragdoll system, better effects and lighting, and fancier water.
    [*] Lots of new unused materials that weren't in the files of the original release.
    [*] A fairly ok excuse to play Half-Life again 
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
    [*] Too many bugs to count
    [*] Absolutely no graphical updates other than the use of the HD Model but they can already be used in the original.
    [*] Wayyyy too many bugs.
[/list]

Overall, Half-Life Source isn't a terrible game just really inferior to the 1999 Original, you're better off playing that or picking up the highly superior Black Mesa remake.

A software bug is an error, flaw or fault in a computer program or system that causes it to produce an incorrect or unexpected result, or to behave in unintended ways. The process of finding and fixing bugs is termed "debugging" and often uses formal techniques or tools to pinpoint bugs, and since the 1950s, some computer systems have been designed to also deter, detect or auto-correct various computer bugs during operations.

Most bugs arise from mistakes and errors made in either a program's source code or its design, or in components and operating systems used by such programs. A few are caused by compilers producing incorrect code. A program that contains many bugs, and/or bugs that seriously interfere with its functionality, is said to be buggy (defective). Bugs can trigger errors that may have ripple effects. Bugs may have subtle effects or cause the program to crash or freeze the computer. Other bugs qualify as security bugs and might, for example, enable a malicious user to bypass access controls in order to obtain unauthorized privileges.

Some software bugs have been linked to disasters. Bugs in code that controlled the Therac-25 radiation therapy machine were directly responsible for patient deaths in the 1980s. In 1996, the European Space Agency's US$1 billion prototype Ariane 5 rocket had to be destroyed less than a minute after launch due to a bug in the on-board guidance computer program. In June 1994, a Royal Air Force Chinook helicopter crashed into the Mull of Kintyre, killing 29. This was initially dismissed as pilot error, but an investigation by Computer Weekly convinced a House of Lords inquiry that it may have been caused by a software bug in the aircraft's engine-control computer.[1]

While [i]Half-Life[/i] is a well-aged masterpiece, [i]Half-Life: Source[/i] is a useless graphics upgrade meant to steal your money.

Having recently just finished the original version of this classic, I tried out a few different parts of it in this [i]Source[/i] version to see the difference and... failed to see the reason this exists. Minimal graphic enhancement and small improvements make this a worthless purchase, playing the original is just fine on its own. If I wanted [i]Half-Life[/i] with better looking water, I would've found some free mod to improve this aspect, not bought a useless version of an already stylistically beautiful game. Although the graphics are outdated since it was released two decades ago, it doesn't mean it needed a flimsy graphical upgrade, I'd rather just purchase the upcoming [i]Black Mesa[/i], at least then it would be a real remastering of the visuals. I know this wasn't an option decades ago, but nonetheless, I would've just preferred the original. The graphical upgrade isn't always an upgrade either, faces on models can become abhorrent in this grotesque "update", and ruin the charm of the original models, creating an entirely new unintentional horror in a game filled with them.

The load times are by far the most infuriating part of this whole [i]Source[/i] edition of the game. They are way longer than they should be when running on a modern PC, and it slows down any sort of fluidity gained in between segments. Having a high-end computer and having load times that can take possibly over a minute is beyond ridiculous, and nails the coffin shut on this awful experience.

If you are trying to decide which version to play this game in, I highly recommend the original. Though slightly graphically inferior, overall it will be more graphically consistent and you won't get a buggy embarrassment like [i]Half-Life: Source[/i]. If you can't live without a slight upgrade, then play this version, but it's pretty obvious which one is inferior, at least for me.

[b][RATING: 5.3/10][/b]

Impossible to complete this game because of HECU Apache Chopper. It's nearly impossible to destroy the chopper because of strange hitbox. Unless you use cheat or you're just a pro you may not proceed as well. And the texture doesn't support HD textures that existed in original Half-Life. But Great Physics than the original, Water texture looks good, etc.

Instead I would recommend you buy the Black Mesa, the remake version of original Half-Life game.

I don't know why everybody rags on HL:Source. I quess that falls into two categories: those who wanted more, and those who   got bit by bugs too hard. Starting with the first, I think as a 'remaster' or a 'rebuild' it's quite good. It actually is just more of a rebuild, nothing is really remastered at all, except for the mountain scene (adds a 3d skybox) and prolly other less significatn areas. [u]Fun fact, my favourite area in Black Mesa is that lil area in the Office Complex with the brown walls and the coffee machine.[/u] So if it's _just_ a straight upgrade to a new engine, then I'm actually fairly impressed with how it looks (and feels). The textures in the world just look better, and the shinyness and 'new' lighting makes everything certainly look smoother. With the water texture and various other small upgrades, it doesn't (intentionally) disrupt the aestheic at all. In my opinion/estimation.

Now the bugs! Hmm, I thought it was minimal, and that everybody was fussing about nothing. I didn't encounter any blocker bugs, but I'm sure there might be one. Hmm. Well, I mean, everything was fine, as far as I could tell. A scientist before the Resonance Cascade was floating above his chair, the vending machines don't heal you anymore, and I some other small quibbles I forgot about it.

So everything seemed fine. Then my save game got corrupted (near the end of Forget About Freeman chapter iirc). Lel. In fact every subsequent game save I made was corrupted until I restarted the game. [b]So I quess there's that.[/b] I mean, that's a blocker bug! At that point I was more or less soon to just turn on god mode and finish it, so it wasn't a big deal, but I suppose, maybe, if you really want a complete Half-Life campaign experience, you should be wary of this, but I contend that the engine upgrade is worth it, but again, save game corruption is a big deal I suppose. [spoiler]I sped-ran the whole game last night, with the last third using cheats. It might have been the second time I've ever gotten all the way to Xen and completed the game. The first time was when I was a kid in my childhood home, and the gman gave his finale and I've been obsessed with the mystery ever since.[/spoiler]

Half-Life is a good game, but the source version is a fucking mess and it's disgusting that Valve is even associated with this particular title. A buggy catastrophe. I had never played the original Half-Life and figured the source version would be better, but I was very foolish to think this. Many things are now absent from this that were in the original, such as extra dialogue between NPCs you could listen to like the bathroom conversation. NPCs that take damage will continuously play pain sounds until they drive you insane. Helicopter hitboxes are extremely small and can't be hit with anything besides a pistol, and it only takes under 2 glock magazines to kill helicopters on "hard" difficulty. Overall not worth the headache. Stay far away from Half-Life: Source. Buy the GoldSrc version, the original. I will have to buy it later to experience this game the right way, and I really shouldn't have to because that's supposed to be the purpose of this game, and it failed miserably, not unlike the third Reich or the Soviet Union.

Remaster do Half Life (1998), que funciona perfeito nos sistemas atuais, jogabilidade boa e desafiante em algumas partes, a dificudade em geral e excelente (talvez você demore um pouco em alguns dos capitulos mas é de boa) o ponto principal aqui vai pra historia que é bem complexa mas se prestar atenção nos dialogos da pra entender, falando nos dialogos não a cutscene é tudo contado no gameplay, (mas não se preocupe, que os dialogos não ocorrem durante o confronto com os inimigos, então da pre escutar de boa). O jogo não possui legendas (é um jogo antigo então ok, mas como esse é o remaster ele poderiam ter adicionado mas tudo bem fazer o que né!), voltando a historia, ela e muito interessante faz você pensar, criar teorias e tals, contada de uma forma diferente e bem feita! A gameplay é facil e qualquer um que tenha jogado CS 1.6 vai se dar bem aqui já que é basicamente igual, as armas são bem diferentes entre si e tem algumas armas especiais que são muito boas por sinal, tambem a uma boa variadede de inmigos considerando o ano em que foi lançado vai rodar em quaquer PC (isso é óbvio), e eu recomendo pra quem gosta de FPS, uma ótima historia com um gameplay rápido e controles simples.
De 0 a 10 eu daria um 9.5 pela historia que é realmente ótima e impressionantemente bem desenvolvida e da forma que é contada, e também pela gameplay! fora que ele ta baratinho, e se você compra ele em promoção (que foi o meu caso) R$2.00 e quase dado kkkk

Half Life is a great Classic like Red Faction, from the 2000 era. It's a very fun FPS with plenty of creatures to shoot at and platforms to cross, quests are minor as it's fairly linear and few deviations. This is so fun i must recommend a play through, but don't expect cutting edge Graphics. "We have work for you, in the Test Chamber" lol ... Have Fun

Half-Life: Source should have and could have been so much more. Unfortunately, despite its name, this isn't so much a "Source" version of Half-Life, but rather just a shinier version of the original iteration. There is no reason to pick this over the original 1998 Half-Life, and let me explain why. 
The fact that the game is hardly any different-looking to its predecessor is the worst part - textures haven't changed a bit, the voice lines are still fuzzy-sounding and muffled... even some explosions have that icky 2-D look to them. For a "Source" game it really is just a slightly enhanced Goldsource game. Even the soundtrack is partially missing because all the loading screens snuff them out before they can even begin, and this game has LOTS of loads. Example: in the chapter "We've Got Hostiles" you'll step into a lift that will take you up to a bad-ass fight scene with your first soldier enemies. Well, the music is stopped dead in its tracks when the loading screen hits. Seriously? They couldn't amend that?
Even with H.D models enabled, the game just isn't different enough. If there's one thing that saves this game (yes, ONE thing) it's the inclusion of rag-doll physics. Smashing your crowbar into an unsuspecting scientist's face and watching them fall to the floor like a bag of sugar never gets old. And that's really it. 
Not to mention, even if you haven't played Half-Life before, and will gladly go for the Source version, the expansion packs were never given the same "treatment". On Steam, both Opposing Force and Blue Shift are Goldsource games. So why play this one game on a very wonky (and early) Source engine? 
Oh, and you probably saw this coming, but Half-Life: Source is incredibly broken. Fans have speculated that the game was merely an experiment by Valve to see how well Source mods could translate from Goldsource games, and I actually don't doubt this theory. The tongues on the barnacle aliens are basically invisible, the hit-boxes are completely messed up (I dare you to try and shoot down ONE enemy helicopter in this game), the A.I for enemies and companions is all wonkier now and gun "idle" animations are tediously repetitive. 
And I have no idea what Valve bonehead was in charge of this project, but I'd like to know who thought it was a good idea to put a doorknob sound effect to signify that the floor is about to collapse.  
One of the more less-talked-about screw-ups in this game is the dreaded Blast Pit screen on the main menu. If you're unlucky enough to be given this menu when starting up the game, enjoy the sound of constant rapid gunfire as the tentacle monsters try to slam continuously into the invincible security guard on the landing. Have fun, headphone users! You can't make this up. 
So if I haven't made it clear enough already, MAYBE just stick to the 1998 version. If it's a "modern" experience you're after, just go play the fan-made mod Black Mesa. It is a thousand times better than this port, and a million times more respectable.
